XLIII PP 425-443 103
It is surprising that so little has been done
in the way of agriculture in Angola
raisingRaising wheat by means of irrigation has
never been tried no plough has ever used
and the only instrument is the native hoe
in the hands of slaves The chief ofbject
of agriculture is the manioc which does not
contain nutriment sufficient to give
proper stamina to the people The half
breed Portuguese have not so much energy as
their fathers They subsist chiefly on the manioc
and as that can be eaten either raw, roasted
or boiled as it comes from the ground or fermented
in water and then roasted or dried after fermentation
and baked or pounded into thin meal or
rasped into meal and cooked as "farina" or
made into a confectionaery with butter and sugar
248 21 241
C L London
Hadley joining 24
Hadley Green
Barnet June
Barnet June DS 23d they it does not so soon pall upon their palates
as one might imagine when told that it is
constitutes their principal food The leaves, boiled
make an excellent vegetable for ^ the table and
when eaten by goats their milk is much
increased The wood is a good fuel and
yields a large quantity of potash. If planted
in a dry soil it takes two years to come to
perfection requiring during that time one
weeding only It bears droughts well
and never shrivels up like other plants when
deprived of rain When planted in low
alluvial soils and either well supplied with
rain or annually flooded one year or even
ten months are sufficient to bring it to maturity

The root rasped while raw and placed
upon a cloth having water and rubbed
104
with the hands while water is poured upon it
parts with its starch and that when it settles
at into the bottom of the vessel and the water
poured away off is placed in the sun till
nearly dry forms Tapioca The process of drying is completed
oven an iron plate over a slow fire the mass
being stirred meanwhile with a stick & when
quite dry it appears agglutinatedconglomerated into little
globules and is ^ in the form we see the tapioca of commerce
This is never eaten by wevilsweevils and so little
labour is required in its cultivation that on
the spot it is extremely cheap In
Throughout the interior parts of Angola
fine manioc meal which could with ease
be converted into either superiorfine starch or tapioca
is commonly sold at the rate of about
ten pounds for a penny. All this region
however ^ has no means of transport ˄ to LoandaLuanda other than the shoulders
of the carriers and slaves by me over a footpath

Cambambe to which the ^ canoe navigation
of the Coanza reaches is reported to be thirty
leagues below Pungo Andongo A large waterfall
is the limit on that side and another exists
higher up at the confluence of the Lombe
over which hippopotami and elephants
are sometimes drawn and killed The
river between is rapid and generally
rushes over a rocky bottom Its source
is pointed out as S. E.South East of its confluence with
the Lombe & near Bihé I had the happiness
of doing a little good in the way of administering
to the sick for theirthere are no doctors in the
interior of Angola bu Notwithstanding
the general healthiness of this fine climate
105
and its pleasant temperature I was attacked by
fever myself While confined to my room a
gentleman of colour who was a canon of the church
kindly paid me a visit He was on a tour of
visitations in the different interior districts for
the purpose of baptizing and marrying He had
lately been on a visit to Portugal Lisbon in company
with the Prince of Congo and had been invested
with an order of honour by the King of Portugal
as an acknowledgement of his services. He had
all the appearance of a true negro but wcommanded
the respect of the people and ColColonel P.Pires who had
known him for thirty years pronounced him to be a
good man There are only three or four
priests in LoandaLuanda all men of colour but
educated for the office About the time of
my journey in Angola an offer was made to
any young man ^ men of ability who might wish to devote
themselves to the service of the church to afford
them the requisite education at the University
of Coimbra in Portugal I was informed ^ by various
on what seemed
good authority
that the Prince of Congo is professedly a Christian
and that there are no fewer than twelve churches
in that Kingdom ---- The fruits of the mission
established in former times at ^ San Salvador
the capital These churches are kept in
some repair by the people who also keep up
the ceremonies of the church pronouncing some
gibberish over the dead in imitation of the latinLatin
prayers which they ^ had formerly heard
Many of them can read and write
When a King of Congo dies the body is wrapped
up in a great many folds of cloth until a
priest can come from LoandaLuanda to consecrate
106
his successor The King of Congo still
retains the title of Lord of Angola which he had
when the Jinga the original possessors
of the soil owned him
allegiance were his vassalsowned him allegiance as well as the original
possessors of the province And when he writes to the
Governor of Angola he places his own name first
as if addressing his vassal The Jinga
paid him tribute annually in cowries which
were found on the island that shelters LoandaLuanda harbour
and refusing to continue payment the
King of Congo gave over the island to the Portuguese
and thus their dominion commenced in this quarter

There is not much knowledge of the the Christian religionChristianity in
either Congo or Angola but yet it is looked
upon with some degree of favour The prevalence
of the fever is probably the reason why no
priest occupies a post in any part of the
interior They come on tours of visitation
like the present and it is said that no
expense is incurred for the people are
ready ^ not only to pay
for their services but
also to furnish them with every article in
their power gratuitously In view of
the desolate condition of this fine missionary
field it is more than probable that the presence
of a few Protestants would soon provoke the
Priests, if not to love, to good works

1st JanyJanuary 1855. Having through the kindness of
ColColonel Pires reproduced some `of my lost papers I
left Pungo Andongo the first day `of this year
and at Candumba slept in one `of his
the dairy establishments of my friend who
had sent forward orders for an ample
supply of butter cheese & milk Our path
lay along 'the right bank ` 'of the Coanza till
When it whichThis is composed of the same
107
sandstone rock with pebbles as forms the
flooring of the country. It is level The land is
level ^ has much open
forest and ^ is well adapted for pasturage

On reaching the confluence of 'the Lombe we left
the river and proceeded in a N ENorth East direction ^ to through
a fine open green country to the village of
Malange where we cut struck our former
path A few miles to the West `of this a
path branches off to a new district named
the Duke Braganza This path crosses
the Lucalla and several of its feeders - The
whole of thatthe country ^ drained by
which are is described as extremely
fertile. The territory West of Braganza is
reported to be mountainous, well wooded and
watered, wild coffee is abundant and the people
even make their
huts of coffee trees The rivers
Dande Senza and Lucalla are said to rise
in one mountain range The numerousNumerous
tribes inhabit the country to 'the NNorth, who are all
independent but 'The Portuguese
power isextends chiefly over 'the tribes through
whose lands we have passed It They may
be said to be ^ not firmly seated ^ only between 'the rivers
Dande Senza ^ and Coanza It extends inland
about 300 miles andor to
the river Quango - and the
population according to
the imimperfect data afforded
by the census given by
annually by the commandants of
the twelvethirteen or fourteen
fifteen or sixteen ^ districts into which it is
divided cannot be under
600 000 souls. Leaving
Malange we passed quickly without
deviation along 'the path by which we had come
430-439 108
already erected at 'the different sleeping places
all their care was bestowed in making me comfortable
--- Mashauana as usual took made his bed
with his head close to my feet and never during
the whole jourl entire journey did I have to call
him twice for anything I needed During our stay ^ my While at this
Tala Mungongo our attention was attracted to
a species `of red ant which infests different parts
`of this country itIt is remarkably fond `of animal
food The commander `of this village having
slaughtered a cow, slaves were obliged to sit up
the whole night burning fires `of straw around
the meat to prevent them ^ from devouring al it the
most of it. These ants isare frequently met with
as in numbers like a littlesmall army. cross At a
little distance they appear as a brownish
red band two or three inches wide stretched across
the path all eagerly pressing on in one direction
If a person happens to tread upon them they
rush up his legs and bite with surprising vigour

The first time I encountered this by no means
contemptible enemy was near Cassange when
My attention being taken up in viewing 'the distant
landscape I accidentally stepped upon one `of
their nests Not an instant seemed to elapse
before a simultaneous attack was made on
various ^ unprotected parts m up the trowserstrousers from below
and on 'the skin my neck ^ & breast above, The bites `of these
furies was like sparks `of fire and there was
no retreat I jumped about for a second
or two then in desperation tore off all my clothing ^ and
&and rubbed & picked them off as quickly as possible se
seriatim Ugh! They would make the most lethargic mortal
look alive - fortunatelyFortunately no one observed
this renconterrencontre or word amight have been
109
taken back to 'the village that I had become mad

I was once assaulted in a similar way when
sound asleep oneat night in my tent, and it was
only by holding my blanket over 'the fire that I
could get rid `of them It is really astonishing
how such small bodies can contain so large an
amount of ill nature They not only bite but
twist their bodies around
after 'the mandibles are
inserted to produce
laceration and pain
more than would be
effected by 'the single
wound frequentlyFrequently while
sitting on the ox as he happened to tread near a
band they rushed up along his legs to 'the rider
and let soon let him know that he had he had disturbed
their march They are very useful in
ridding 'the country `of dead animal matter
and when they visit a human habitation they clean
it entirely ` 'of the white destructive white ants and
other vermin They possess no fear attacking
with equal ferocity 'the largest as well as 'the smallest
animals When any oneperson has leaped
over 'the band numbers of them
leave 'the ranks and
rush along 'the path seemingly
anxious for a fight They keep downdestroy many noxious
insects and reptiles The severity `of their
attack bite is greatly increased by their vast numbers
and rats, mice lizards and even 'the python
natalensis when in a state `of surfeit from
recent feeding fall a victims to their fierce
onslaught. These ants never make
hills like the white ant. Their nests are
but a short distance beneath 'the soil and appear
on 'the surface which has the same soft appearance
that of ^ the abodes of ants in England Occasionally
they construct galleries over their path to the
cells of 'the white ant in order to secure themselves
from the heat ` 'of the sun in their during their marauding
expeditions.

JanJanuary 15 /551855 We descended from 'the heights `of Tala
MungongaMungongo this mor, It in one hour I
counted 'the number `of paces made on 'the slope downward
110
wh and found them to be between sixteen hundred wh.which may
give a perpendicular height `of from twelve to fifteen
hundred ft.feet Water boiled at 206° at
Tala MungongaMungongo above and at 208° at 'the bottom
of 'the declivity. The air being at 72° in 'the shade
in 'the former case and 94° in 'the latter The temp-
erature generally throughout 'the day was 9 from
94° to 97° in 'the coolest shade we could find

The rivulets wh.which cut up 'the valley `of Cassange
were now dry but 'the Lui and Luare contained
abundance `of rather brackish water. The banks
are lined with ^ pPalm and wild date trees, many
guavas the fruit `of wh.which was now becoming ripe
A tree much like 'the abounds but it
does not yield fruit In these rivers a kind
`of edible muselmussel ^ abounds is plentiful shells `of wh.which exist in all 'the
alluvial lands beds ` 'of the ancient rivers as far as
'the Kuruman. The brackish nature ` 'of the water
probably enables it to exist here, Before we
reached Cassange we were overtaken by 'the Com-
mandant Sn.Senhor Carvalho ^ who was returning with a
detachment `of fifty men and a field
piece from an unsuccessful search after
some rebels. The rebels had fled and all
that he could do was to burn their huts, he
kindly invited me to take up my residence
(? with him but not wishing to pass by the
gentleman who had so CaptCaptain
Neves who had so kindly I had concluded to return to
'the hospitable mansion of 'the Gentleman CaptCaptain
Neves who had first received me on my ^ first arrival
in 'the Portuguese possessions I declined. SnSenhor Rego had
been superseded in his command, because
'the present GovrGovernor Amaral who had come ^ into office since my departure from to LoandaLuanda since
my departure from
my departure had determined that 'the law
which requires 'the office `of Commandant to be
111
exclusively occupied by military officers of 'the line
should again come into operation. I was again
most kindly welcomed by my friend CaptCaptain Neves
whom I found labouring under a violent inflamationinflammation
and abscess of 'the hand There is nothing in 'the
situation `of this village to indicate unhealthiness
except perhaps 'the rank luxuriance ` 'of the vegetation
Nearly all 'the Portuguese inhabitants however suffer from
enlargement of 'the spleen the effects `of frequent
intermittents and ^ have generally a sickly appearance many ` 'of the children are cut off

Thinking that this affection ` 'of the hand was simply
an effort `of nature to get rid of malarious matter
from 'the system I recommended 'the use `of quinine. ^
He himself
applied Thethe and 'the leaf `of a plant called Cathory famed
among 'the people ^ natives as an excellent remedy for
ulcers being applied each medicine remedy of
course claimed the merit ` 'of the cure The Cathory
leaves when boiled exude a gummy juice
wh.which effectually shuts out the external air

Many ` 'of the children are cut off by fever
A fine boy of CaptCaptain Neves had since my passage
westward shared a similar fate Another child
died during the period of my visit and the
It third being now sick his mother, a woman of colour
sent for a diviner in order to ascertain what ought
to be done. The diviner after throwing his dice
p worked himself into athe state of extacyecstasy in
which they pretend to be in communication with
the gods Barimo He then gave the oracular
response that "the child was being killed by the
spirit `of a Portuguese trader who once lived
at Cassange" The case was this on the
death ` 'of the above trader the other Portuguese
merchants in 'the village came together
112
and sold 'the goods ` 'of the departed to each other, each
man accounting for 'the portion he took to 'the creditors
of 'the deceased at LoandaLuanda The natives looking
on and not understanding 'the nature `of written
mercantile transactions concluded that the
merchants `of Cassange had simply stolen the
dead mansman's goods and that now 'the spirit was
killing 'the child `of CaptCaptain Neves for 'the part he had
in the affair. The diviner in his response
showed revealed 'the impression made on his own
mind by 'the sale and likewise 'the native ideas of
departed souls. As they give 'the whites
credit for greater stupidity than themselves
in all these matters the mother ` 'of the child
came and told the father that he ought to
to give a slave
to the diviner
as payment
for ^ making a sacrifice to appease 'the spirit and
save 'the life ` 'of the child. The father quietly
sent for a neighbour and though the diviner
pretended to remain in his state of extacyecstasy
the brisk application of two sticks to his back
suddenly reduced him to his senses and a pre-
cipitate flight a most undignified flight

The mother `of this child seemed to
have no confidence in European wisdom
and though I desired her to keep 'the child out of
currents `of wind she preferred to follow her
own custom and even got it cupped in 'the
cheeks The consequence was ^ that the child was
soon in a dying state and 'the Father wishing
it to be baptized I performed commended
its soul to 'the care & compassion of him who
said Of such is 'the Kingdom of Heaven
The mother at once rushed away and commenced
that doleful wail wh.which is so affecting as
113
it indicates sorrow without hope She continued
it without intermission until 'the child was buried
on the evening ^ Her female companions em used a small
musical instrument which produced a kind of
screaking sound as an accompaniment of 'the ^ death wail

---- In the construction of this instrument
they make use of cahouchou caoutchouc wh.which
with a variety of other gums is found in ^ different parts of this country

The intercourse which 'the natives have had with
white men does not seem to have much
ameliorated their condition. A great
number of persons are reported to lose their
lives annually in different districts `of Angola
by 'the cruel superstitions to wh.which they are addicted
and 'the Portuguese authorities either know nothing of
them or are unable to prevent eradicate them
prevent their occurrence The natives are
bound to secrecy by those who administer the
ordeal wh.which generally causes 'the death ` 'of the victim

A person when accused `of witchcraft
in order to assert her innocency will often
travel from distant districts in order to brave
the test They come to a river in the Cassange
district called Dua and as they drink the
infusion `of a poisonous tree and perish unknown

— A woman was accused by a brother in law
of being 'the cause `of his sickness while we were at
Cassange She offered to take 'the ordeal as they
she had 'the idea that it would but prove the
her conscious innocence of wh.which she was conscious CaptCaptain N.Neves
refused his consent to her going and thus saved
her life whwhich would have been sacrificed for the
poison is very virulent; when a strong stomach
rejects it the accuser and reiteratess his charge
114
the dose is repeated and the person dies, hundreds
perish thus every year in 'the valley `of Cassange

The same superstitious ideas being prevalent
through 'the whole ` 'of the country north of 'the ZambesiZambezi
seems to indicate that 'the people must originally
have been one All beleivebelieve that 'the souls ` 'of the departed
still mingle among 'the living and partake in
some way of 'the food they consume In sickness
sacrifices ^ of fowls and goats are made to appease 'the spirits. It
is imagined that they wish to take 'the living away
from earth and all its enjoyments. When one
has killed another a sacrifice is made
as if to lay 'the spirit of 'the victim. A sect is
reported to exist whothat kills men in order to
take their hearts and offer them to the Barimo
One The mode of succession is extensively prevalent
The sons of a sister
belong to their uncle among all 'the tribes south of the ZambesiZambezi the
nephews by a sister are considered heirs of their
uncle and occupy a spr superior place to his
own children, and The uncles however do not
seem to have much affection for ^ their newphews since they them, as nephews
are often sold to pay his debts. By these customs
more than by war is the slave market supplied
The chieftainship is elective from certain families
among 'the Bangalas `of this Cassange valley the chief
is chosen from three families in rotation A
chiefschief's brother inherits in preference to ahis son. The
sons nephews of a sister belong to her brother and he
often sells his nephews to pay his debts. By
this and other unnatural customs more than
by war is the slave market supplied

---- The prejudices these people in favour
of these practices are very deeply rooted in
the native mind. Even at LoandaLuanda
115
they retire out of 'the city in order to perform their
heathenish rites without the cognizance ` 'of the authorities
Their religion if such it may be called is one of
dread. Numbers of charms are employed to
avert 'the evils with wh.which they feel themselves to be
encompassed - Occasionally you meet a
man more cautious or more timid than the rest
who with twenty or thirty charms hung round his
neck, he seems to act upon 'the principle `of
Proclus in his prayer to all 'the gods & goddesses

---- Among so many he surely must have
'the right one The disrespect whwhich Europeans
pay to 'the objects `of their fear is into their minds
only evidence `of greats folly. The
While here I finished reproduced 'the last `of my lost
papers & maps and and as there is a post sent
twice a month from LoandaLuanda I had 'the happiness to
receive a packet ` 'of the Times givingand among other news an account ` 'of the
Russian war up to the terrible charge of the light cavalry. The intense anxiety I felt to
hear more may be imagined but I by every
? true patriot but I was forced to be content with brood ^ on with in
silent thoughts
& utteredand utter
only my poor prayers for my friends ^ who perchance were now no more until I reached
'the other side ` 'of the continent

A considerable
trade is carried on with by the Cassange merchants
with all 'the surrounding territory by means of
native traders whom they term "Pombeiros"
Two of these called in 'the history of Angola "The
trading blacks" (os feirantes pretos) Pedro
João Baptista, & A and Antonio José
having been sent by a 'the first Portuguese trader who
that lived at Cassenge actually returned
from some ` 'of the Portuguese possessions ^ in the East with
116
letters from 'the GovrGovernor of Mozambique in the
year 1815 proving as wasis remarked "the possibility
of ^ of so important a communication between Mozambique and
LoandaLuanda" This is the only
instance of
native Portuguese
^ subjects crossing the
continent - No
European ever
accomplished
it though the
casefact has lately
been quoted as
if the men had
been "Portuguese" CaptCaptain Neves was now
actively engaged in preparing a present worth
about fifty pounds to be sent by Pombeiros to
Matiamvo It consisted of great quantities
of cotton cloth, a large carpet and an armed-
chair with a canopy and curtains of crimson ^ calico
cotton ^ an iron bedstead, mosquito curtains beads &c
and a number of pictures rudely prpainted in
oil by an embryo black-painter at Cassange

Matiamvo, like most ` 'of the natives in 'the interior of
'the country had a strong wishdesire to possess a cannon
and had sent ten large tusks to purchase one
but it being GovtGovernment property it could not be sold
he was now furnished with a blunderbuss
mounted as a cannon whwhich will probably please
him as well. A Portuguese gentleman
Graça named A Sn.Senhor Grassa and some other
Portuguese have visited this chief at different
times but no European resides beyond 'the Quango
indeed it is contrary to 'the policy ` 'of the GovtGovernment of Angola
to allow their subjects to spre~ad penetrate farther into
'the interior The present would have been a good
opportunity for me to visit the chief and I felt
strongly inclined to do so as he had expressed
⎵ ?some disatisfactiondissatisfaction respecting ^ my /treatment of
by 'the Chiboque and even threatened to punish
them. As it would be improper to force
my men to go thither I resolved to wait and
see whether 'the proposition might not emanate
from themselves. When I can get my men the natives to
agree in 'the propriety `of any step they go to the
117
end ` 'of the affair without a murmur I respeak to
them and treat them as rational beings and
generally get on well with them in consequence

I have already remarked on the
unhealthiness `of Cassange aand CaptCaptain Neves
who possesses an enqu observing turn `of mind
had remarked that always when 'the west wind
blows much fever immediately follows
As long as Eastern⎵erly winds prevail all enjoy
good health but in JanyJanuary FebFebruary March & April
they ^ winds are variable and sickness is general extensively prevails
---- The season of theThe unhealthiness of 'the westerly
winds probably results from malaria being
appearing to be heavier than common air out is sweeping rolleding down
into 'the valley of Cassange from 'the western ^ plateau and acts
flows somewhat in 'the same way as the carbonic
acid gas from bean fields
is supposed by colliers to do -
into coal pits - In the west
of Scotland strong objections
are made by that body
of men to farmers planting
beans in their vicinity
from the belief that they
render the mines unhealthy
The gravitatingon of the malaria
from the more elevated
land of Tala Mungongo
towards Cassange is
the only way the unhealthiness
of this spot on the
prevalence of the Westerly
winds can be accounted
for - The banks of the
118
Quango though much more
marshy and covered
with more ranker vegetation
are comparatively healthy
but thither the westerly
wind does not seem to
convey the noxious agent
FebFebruary 20 On the day of starting from
Cassange, the westerly wind
blew strongly and on
the day following we
were brought to a
stand by several of our
party being laid up of
fever This complaint
is the only serious drawback
Angola possesses - It is
in every other respect an
agreeable land and admirably
adapted for yielding a
a in rich abundance of
tropical produce for the
rest of the world - Indeed I
have no hesitation in asserting
that had it been in the
possession of the English England it would
Indeed now have been yielding as much supportof the raw
or 2more 1materials tofor her manufactures as an equal extent of
territory in the So cotton growing states of North
America. A railway from LoandaLuanda to this
valley would secure 'the trade `of most ` 'of the interior of
South Central Africa. As soon as we could
move onward towards 'the Quango we did so,
meeting in our course several trading parties
119
both native and Portuguese. ^ We met Two men belonging
to We met two ` 'of the latter carrying a tusk weighing
one hundred and twenty six pounds. The owner afterwards
informed us that its fellow on the left side ` 'of the same
elephant was one hundred and thirty pounds. It
was eight feet 6½1/2 inches long and 21 inches in
circumference at 'the part on wh.which 'the lip ` 'of the animal
rests. The elephant was rather a small one
as they are in is common in this hot central region
Some idea may be formed ` 'of the strength `of his neck when
it is recollected that he bore a weight `of 256lbspounds

The ivory whwhich comes from 'the east & N. E.North East `of Cassange
is very much larger than any to be found further
South ColColonel CaptCaptain Neves had one weighing 120lbspounds
and this weight is by no means uncommon
They have been found ^ weighing even 158lbspounds. Before
reaching 'the Quango we were again brought to a
stand by fever in two `of my companions close to
athe residence of a Portuguese who rejoiced in 'the name `of
William Tell & who lived here on 'the banks of 'the QRiver
in spite ` 'of the prohibition ` 'of the GovtGovernment the policy being

We were using 'the water `of a pond and this gentleman
having come to invite me to dinner drank a little
of some ^ it and caught fever in consequence
If malarious matter exists in water it would
have been a wonder if we escaped, for travelling
in 'the sun with and ^ with 'the thermometer in 'the pocket
on 'the shady side being always from 96° to 98° in 'the shade the
evaporation from our bodies causeding much thirst
we generally partook of every water we came to
We had probably thus more disease than others
might suffer who had better shelter

Mr Tell remarked that his garden was
rather barren being still as he said wild
120
in funeral orgies. He acted with his wonted
kindness though unfortunately drinking has got him
so deeply into debt that he now keeps out ` 'of the way
`of his creditors. He informed us that the
source of the Quango is ^ 8 days or one hundred miles to 'the south of this and in
a range called Mosamba in the country of 'the
Basongo. We can see from this a sort of break
in 'the highland wh.which stretches away round to Tala
Mongongo through wh.which the river comes

A death had occurred in a village about a mile
off the people were busy beating drums & firing
festive guns - aThe funeral isrites are half feasting, half-
mourning ,and partaking somewhat ` 'of the character of
an Irish wake. TheirThere is nothing more
heartrending than their death-wails. When
they natives turn their eyes to 'the future world they
have a cheerless2 enough3 view1 - `of their own utter
? helplessness & hopelessness. They fancy themselvthemselves
completely in 'the power `of thise departed disembodied
spirits and look
upon 'the proba prospect `of following theirm as the
greatest of misfortunes. Hence they are
constantly deprecating 'the wrath of departed
spirits believing that if they are appeased there
is no other cause `of death wh.which but
witchcraft wh.which cmay be averted by charms

The whole ` 'of the coloured population of
Angola are described as sunk in these
